>And despite the haze, thick and warm like an opiate, Hunter saw her at the end of the bar, feet dangling from the chair, a half-empty bottle of vodka within reach of her stubby arms: Summer Keaton, the pembroke corgi; his lifeline out here in this frosted shithole. Anonymous Mon 25 Jan 2021 04:35:25 No.35798709 Report
Quoted By: >>35798951 >>35799021
>>35797656
Be brisk with past tense third person. Try to keep an active voice, especially in visual description. And lean into description to convey events. Second and first person live more in a single character's head and perceptions, while third person more easily allows smoother transition from perspectives - if you want to go that route, it isn't required but more available.
Anonymous
  • Post
  • Report

Anonymous Mon 25 Jan 2021 04:48:41 No.35799021 Report
Quoted By: >>35799057 >>35800213 >>35806358
>>35798494
I know that stage you're at. You've got the same issue I do: the similes and metaphors that come out in a first draft feel like they drag things down.
One of my other pieces feels really dry right now. The story is in your head, right? But it's like reading a screenplay instead of watching the final cut.
I've found that if I can leave emotional cues to build on, like you have with Summer pouring her drink, the rest will flow.

>>35798709
Brisk works, but I've found that laying back on the pacing works just as well. If the writer is aware of when to let a scene breathe, or take a conversation/scene towards a character-based mode rather than plot based, he can move along both axes.
>Try to keep an active voice
And that can be hard. Sometimes the passive voice is far more concise for description.
But that comes back to my point. Control the pacing for the moment you're in. It takes practice, but that's what first drafts are for.

Anonymous Mon 25 Jan 2021 05:00:53 No.35799290 Report
Quoted By:
>>35798951
>third person is so sterile
It's subtle. Telling is really easy in first or second. It takes skill to do those and get out of the way of the characters talking/moving. That's when they're knocking at that showing line.
Third? It's going to quickly highlight how little you've practiced showing.
The good thing is when I've practiced third person, my first person gets way better.

>>35799057
>can't find the flavor
Notes, outlining, summaries...
I've noticed the experienced writefags here do some of it, but the key is not waiting for inspiration. The flavor will come after you do the dirty work of pouring a foundation.

>>35799114
like >>35799057 said, build off the emotions behind the actions. Don't overthink it. Just get it the fuck down on the page and step out of your own head/experiences later.

Anonymous Mon 25 Jan 2021 12:44:08 No.35806358 Report
Quoted By: >>35806808 >>35806930 >>35810107
>>35799021
>Metaphor getting dense
Use shorter, closer-to-home examples. Metaphors and similes work a lot like memes: the idea is to shortcut to a complex idea by describing it in terms of some familiar, shared experience. If you're speaking from the perspective of a character, especially in first person, the comparisons "they" pick should reflect their present attitude, but your priority should always be that the reader understands exactly what you mean in as few words as possible. Get creative, and don't shy away from the benign or, depending on narrative tone, absurd. Yahtzee Croshaw is actually really good at this; I recommend watching some Zero Punctuation really any time you want a reference for being both specific and brief.
Anonymous

  • Report

I'm that way with dialogue
The key is going back later and fleshing out the piece

>>35806358
Your point is valid, but what I was getting at was not letting things bog down in memetics when doing the first draft. Chances are you already see the flaws; that's the density for you. The writer don't need to be clever...yet.
Editing involves cleaning up one's first draft shortcomings. And that may be too few words as well.
I've been thinking more recently on pacing, and being more conscious of what I want per sentence & paragraph keeps me from overthinking the big picture.

I think the primitive life style and culture of the Ewoks makes them cool, and I haven't really explored the wild side of anthros in many of my stories. Ewoks in the lore can be brutal, resourceful killers, living on the edge of savagery, and George Lucas himself said that their tactics in combat were inspired by the Viet Cong. Their interactions with both the Empire and the Rebel Alliance also create a lot of depth to work within.
I also think that the design of Ewoks rides the line between adorable and hideous, which is where I like my alien species to be.

>>35806930
In my experience its way the hell easier to overwrite first rather than underwrite. My methodology isn't very deliberate, though. I feel scenes out and then cut and abandon as necessary, but if you treat writing in an FDM printer sort of way I could see doing it the other way around. It would certainly be easier to not get overwhelmed. Personally I tend to get very hung up on rhythm and sentence structure and start to lose my train of thought, which is probably the biggest thing that fucks my release schedule. For those who write the way I do, I don't have a good answer for that other than to just keep going and try not to worry about it.

Seconded on self-publishing.

Self publish for a while, learn the business, and take your knocks.
